en.title: Divorce application (petition)
en.divorceRoleExplain: The applicant is the person who has applied for a divorce (legally known as the petitioner). The respondent is their husband or wife.
en.coRespRoleExplain: The co-respondent is the person the applicant claims the respondent committed adultery with.
en.whoTheMarriageNames: {{ session.originalPetition.marriagePetitionerName }} and {{ session.originalPetition.marriageRespondentName }} (as shown on the marriage certificate)
en.marriageDetailsExplained: These details are copied exactly from the marriage certificate, or a translation of the certificate if it’s not in English. The names on the certificate are the names that the applicant and respondent used before the marriage.
en.whyTheCourtHeading: Why the court can deal with the case (jurisdiction)
en.theCourtsOfEngland: The courts of England and Wales must have the jurisdiction (the legal power) to be able to grant a divorce. The applicant confirmed that the legal statement, or statements, given in the application apply to either, or both the applicant and respondent.
en.eachLegalStatement: Each legal statement includes some or all of the following legal connections to England and Wales.
en.habitualResidencePar1: If your lives are mainly based in England or Wales then you’re what is legally known as 'habitually resident'.
en.habitualResidencePar2: This may include working, owning property, having children in school, and your main family life taking place in England or Wales.
en.habitualResidencePar3: The examples above aren’t a complete list of what makes up habitual residence, and just because some of them apply to you doesn’t mean you’re habitually resident. If you’re not sure, you should get legal advice.
en.domicilePar1: Your domicile is usually the place in which you were born, regard as your permanent home and to which you have the closest ties.
en.domicilePar2: However, domicile can be more complex if you or your parents have moved countries in the past.
en.domicilePar3: When you’re born, you acquire a domicile of origin. This is usually:
en.domicileList1: the country your father considered his permanent home if your parents were married
en.domicileList2: the country your mother considered her permanent home if your parents were unmarried, or your father had died
en.domicilePar4: If you leave your domicile of origin and settle in another country as an adult, the new country may become your domicile of choice.
en.domicilePar5: If you’re not sure about your domicile you should get legal advice.
en.otherCourtCasesPar1: The court needs to know if there any other court cases which might affect the jurisdiction of the court, and its decision to grant a divorce.
en.claimingCostsPar1: Your {{ divorceWho }} was asked if they want the court to order you to pay some or all of the divorce costs. If your {{ divorceWho }} is using adultery as the reason for divorce and has chosen to name the co-respondent, they can also be asked to pay for some of the costs.
en.claimingCostsPar2: This could include all the fees during the divorce, such as the £{{ feesIssueApplication }} application fee, solicitor fees, and any extra court fees.
en.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar1: Your {{ divorceWho }} was asked if they want the court to decide how your property, money, pensions and other assets will be split.
en.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar2: These decisions are called 'financial orders'. Financial orders can be made between you and your {{ divorceWho }} and for any children you may have.
en.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar3: To formally start legal proceedings, your {{ divorceWho }} will need to complete another form (known as Form A) and pay a fee of £{{ feesDivorceSubmitFormA }}. This means that they don’t have to proceed with the financial order at this point.
en.consentOrdersPar1: If you both agree on how to split your money and property and want to make it legally binding, you can apply for a type of financial order called a 'consent order'.
en.consentOrdersPar2: You’ll need to get a solicitor to draft the consent order, and then send it to the court with a £{{ feesFinancialConsentOrder }} fee.
en.consentOrdersPar3: You should get legal advice if you’re not sure what to do.
en.ordersForChildMaintenancePar: The court can only make financial orders for children under certain circumstances. You’ll usually either need to come to an agreement with your {{ divorceWho }} (which you can then make legally binding with a consent order) or use the Child Maintenance Service.
en.youWillBeAbleToRespond: You will be able to respond to this application on the next page

en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceLegalGround: The only legal ground for divorce in England and Wales is if the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceChosenReaso: The applicant had to choose a reason for the breakdown of the marriage (legally known as the 'fact') from the following list.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceBehaviourDe: The respondent has behaved in such a way that the applicant cannot reasonably be expected to live with them.

The applicant must provide enough examples of the respondent’s behaviour to satisfy the court that they can’t reasonably be expected to live with them. The examples must be of the respondent’s behaviour, and examples where the applicant and respondent are both at fault cannot be used.

If the applicant lives with the respondent as a couple for more than 6 months after the most recent example of behaviour, the court will take this into account in its judgement of whether or not the marriage has broken down irretrievably. This could be over a single 6 month period, or if they live together on and off for several periods adding up to more than 6 months.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceAdulteryDes: The respondent committed adultery, and the applicant finds it intolerable to live with them.
Adultery can only be used if it was with a member of the opposite sex.

The applicant has the option of naming the person with whom the respondent committed adultery (known as the co-respondent). Co-respondents are sent a copy of the divorce application and asked if they want to defend the allegations.

Adultery can’t be used as a reason if the applicant and respondent lived together as a couple for more than 6 months after the applicant found out about it. This could have been in one go, or if they lived together on and off for several periods of time adding up to more than 6 months.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceSeparatedTw: The applicant and respondent must have spent the past 2 years living apart to use this reason for divorce.

They are allowed to have spent some time living together, but only for up to 6 months (over one or more periods) and this time doesn’t count towards the 2 year period. They’ll need to have lived apart for longer to make up any time that they spent living together.
The respondent must give their consent to a divorce for this reason to be used.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceSeparatedFi: The applicant and respondent must have spent the past 5 years living apart to use this reason for divorce.

They are allowed to have spent some time living together, but only for up to 6 months (over one or more periods) and this time doesn’t count towards the 5 year period. They’ll need to have lived apart for longer to make up any time that they spent living together.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceDesertionDe: The respondent left the applicant without their agreement at least 2 years ago, and they have lived apart since.

The applicant and respondent are allowed to have spent some time living together since the desertion, but only for up to 6 months (over one or more periods) and this time doesn’t count towards the 2 year period. They’ll need to have lived apart for longer to make up any time that they spent living together.
The respondent must have chosen to leave the applicant. For example, it can’t be used if they have been sent to prison.

cy.divorceRoleExplain: Y ceisydd yw’r un sydd wedi gwneud cais am ysgariad (yn iaith y gyfraith fe’i gelwir yn ddeisebydd). Yr atebydd yw gŵr neu wraig y ceisydd.

cy.marriageDetailsExplained: Caiff y manylion hyn eu cymryd oddi ar y dystysgrif priodas, neu gyfieithiad o’r dystysgrif os nad yw’n Saesneg. Yr enwau ar y dystysgrif yw’r enwau yr oedd y ceisydd a’r atebydd yn eu defnyddio cyn y briodas.
cy.whyTheCourtHeading: Pam y gall y llys ddelio â’r cais (awdurdodaeth)
cy.theCourtsOfEngland: Rhaid i’r llysoedd yng Nghymru a Lloegr feddu ar yr awdurdodaeth (y pwer cyfreithiol) i roi ysgariad. Mae’r ceisydd wedi cadarnhau bod y datganiad neu’r datgyniadau cyfreithiol, a roddwyd yn y cais yn berthnasol i’r ceisydd neu’r atebydd neu’r ddau ohonynt.
cy.eachLegalStatement: Mae bob datganiad cyfreithiol yn cynnwys rhai o’r cysylltiadau cyfreithiol canlynol â Chymru a Lloegr neu bob un ohonynt.
cy.habitualResidencePar1: Os ydych chi’n treulio’r ran fwyaf o’ch amser yng Nghymru neu Loegr, rydych yn preswylio’n arferol yno yn ôl y gyfraith.
cy.habitualResidencePar2: Mae’n bosib i hyn gynnwys gweithio, bod yn berchen ar eiddo, bod â phlant mewn ysgol, a bod eich prif fywyd teuluol yng Nghymru neu Loegr.
cy.habitualResidencePar3: Nid yw’r enghreifftiau uchod yn rhestr gynhwysfawr o amgylchiadau sy’n enghreifftio preswylfa arferol, ac er y gallai rhai ohonynt fod yn berthnasol ichi, nid yw hynny o reidrwydd yn golygu eich bod yn preswylio’n arferol yn rhywle. Os nad ydych yn siwr , dylech ofyn am gyngor cyfreithiol.
cy.domicilePar1: Fel arfer, eich domisil yw’r lle y cawsoch eich geni, y lle yr ydych yn meddwl amdano fel eich cartref parhaol a’r lle mae eich ffrindiau a’ch teulu agosaf yn byw.
cy.domicilePar2: Ond, mae’n bosib i’ch domisil fod yn fwy cymhleth, er enghraifft os ydych chi neu eich rhieni wedi symud o un wlad i’r llall yn y gorffennol.
cy.domicilePar3: Pan gewch eich geni, byddwch yn cael mamwlad. Fel arfer hon yw’r wlad:
cy.domicileList1: yr oedd eich tad yn ystyried yn gartref parhaol iddo os oedd eich rhieni wedi priodi
cy.domicileList2: yr oedd eich mam yn ystyried yn gartref parhaol iddi os oedd eich rhieni heb briodi, neu os oedd eich tad wedi marw
cy.domicilePar4: Os byddwch yn gadael eich domisil gwreiddiol ac yn ymsefydlu mewn gwlad arall fel oedolyn, yna gallai’r wlad newydd yn dod yn ddomisil dewisol ichi.
cy.domicilePar5: Os nad ydych chi’n siwr am eich domisil, dylech ofyn am gyngor cyfreithiol.
cy.otherCourtCasesPar1: Mae’r llys angen gwybod a oes unrhyw achosion llys eraill a allai effeithio ar awdurdodaeth y llys, a’i benderfyniad i ganiatáu ysgariad.
cy.claimingCostsPar1: Gofynnwyd i’ch {{ divorceWho }} a oedd am i’r llys orchymyn ichi dalu rhywfaint o gostau’r ysgariad neu holl gostau’r ysgariad. Os yw eich {{ divorceWho }} yn defnyddio godineb fel y rheswm dros ysgaru ac os yw wedi dewis enwi eich cyd-atebydd, gellir gofyn i’r cyd-atebydd dalu rhywfaint o’r costau yn ogystal.
cy.claimingCostsPar2: Fe all hyn gynnwys yr holl ffioedd yn ystod yr ysgariad, megis y ffi gwneud cais o £{{ feesIssueApplication }}, ffioedd cyfreithwyr ac unrhyw ffioedd ychwanegol o ran costau’r llys.
cy.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar1: Gofynnwyd i’ch {{ divorceWho }} a oedd eisiau i’r llys benderfynu sut y bydd eich eiddo, eich arian, eich pensiynau a’ch asedau’n cael eu rhannu.
cy.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar2: Gelwir y penderfyniadau hyn yn 'orchmynion ariannol'. Gellir gwneud gorchmynion ariannol rhyngoch chi a’ch {{ divorceWho }} ac ar gyfer unrhyw blant sydd gennych.
cy.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar3: I gychwyn achos cyfreithiol yn ffurfiol, bydd angen i’ch {{ divorceWho }} lenwi ffurflen arall (a elwir yn Ffurflen A) a thalu ffi £{{ feesDivorceSubmitFormA }}. Golyga hyn nad oes rhaid iddynt fwrw ymlaen â’r gorchymyn ariannol ar hyn o bryd.
cy.consentOrdersPar1: Os yw’r ddau ohonoch yn cytuno sut y bydd eich arian a’ch eiddo yn cael ei rannu, a’ch bod eisiau i hynny fod yn gyfreithiol rwymol, gallwch wneud cais am fath o orchymyn ariannol a elwir yn ‘orchymyn cydsynio’.
cy.consentOrdersPar2: Bydd angen i chi ofyn i gyfreithiwr ddrafftio’r gorchymyn cydsynio, ac yna ei anfon i’r llys gyda’r ffi o £{{ feesFinancialConsentOrder }}.
cy.consentOrdersPar3: Dylech gael cyngor cyfreithiol os nad ydych yn siwr beth i’w wneud.
cy.ordersForChildMaintenancePar: Dim ond mewn rhai amgylchiadau neilltuol y gall y llys wneud gorchmynion ariannol i blant. Gan amlaf, bydd angen ichi ddod i gytundeb gyda’ch {{ divorceWho }} (cytundeb y gallwch wedyn ei wneud yn gyfreithiol rwymol gyda gorchymyn cydsynio) neu ddefnyddio’r Gwasanaeth Cynhaliaeth Plant.

cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceLegalGround: Yr unig reswm cyfreithiol dros gael ysgariad yng Nghymru a Lloegr yw bod y briodas wedi chwalu’n gyfan gwbl.
cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceChosenReaso: Roedd rhaid i’r ceisydd ddewis rheswm pam fod y briodas wedi chwalu (a elwir yn gyfreithiol yn 'ffaith') o’r rhestr ganlynol.
cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceBehaviourDe: Roedd yr atebydd wedi ymddwyn yn y fath ffordd fel na ellir yn rhesymol ddisgwyl i’r ceisydd fyw gyda’r atebydd.

Rhaid i’r ceisydd ddarparu digon o enghreifftiau am ymddygiad yr atebydd i fodloni’r llys na ellir yn rhesymol ddisgwyl iddo/iddi fyw gyda’r atebydd. Rhaid i’r enghreifftiau fod o ymddygiad yr atebydd, ac ni ellir defnyddio enghreifftiau lle mae bai ar y ceisydd a’r atebydd.

Os yw’r ceisydd yn byw gyda’r atebydd fel cwpl am fwy na 6 mis ar ôl yr enghraifft ddiweddaraf o ymddygiad, bydd y llys yn cymryd hyn i ystyriaeth wrth benderfynu a yw’r briodas wedi chwalu’n gyfan gwbl. Fe allai hyn fod am un cyfnod o 6 mis, neu am gyfnodau llai dros gyfnod o amser sy’n hirach na 6 mis.
cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceAdultery: Godineb (cael perthynas rywiol gyda dyn/dynes arall)
cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceAdulteryDes: Cyflawnodd yr atebydd odineb, ac mae’r ceisydd yn ei chael hi’n annioddefol byw gydag ef/hi.
Dim ond os oedd yr unigolyn arall o wahanol ryw y gallwch ddefnyddio godineb.

Mae gan y ceisydd yr opsiwn o enwi’r un y mae’r atebydd wedi cyflawni godineb ag ef/hi (y cyd-atebydd). Anfonir copi o’r cais am ysgariad at y cyd-atebydd a gofynnir iddo/iddi a yw am amddiffyn yr honiadau.

Ni ellir defnyddio godineb fel rheswm os bu i’r ceisydd a’r atebydd fyw gyda’i gilydd fel cwpl am fwy na 6 mis ar ôl i’r ceisydd ddod i wybod amdano. Fe allai hyn fod wedi bod am un cyfnod, neu am gyfnodau llai dros gyfnod o amser sy’n hirach na 6 mis.
cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceSeparatedTw: Wedi gwahanu am 2 flynedd drwy gytundeb
Mae’n rhaid i’r ceisydd a’r atebydd fod wedi treulio’r 2 flynedd diwethaf yn byw ar wahân, i allu defnyddio’r rheswm hwn dros gael ysgariad.

Mae ganddynt hawl i fod wedi byw gyda’i gilydd, ond dim ond am hyd at 6 mis (un cyfnod o 6 mis neu sawl cyfnod llai sy’n cyfateb i 6 mis), ac nid yw’r amser hwn yn cyfrif tuag at y cyfnod o 2 flynedd. Mae’n rhaid eu bod wedi byw ar wahân am fwy o amser i wneud i fyny am yr amser y bu iddynt fyw gyda’i gilydd.
Mae’n rhaid i’r atebydd gytuno cyn y gellir rhoi ysgariad am y rheswm hwn.

Mae ganddynt hawl i fod wedi byw gyda’i gilydd, ond dim ond am hyd at 6 mis (un cyfnod o 6 mis neu sawl cyfnod llai sy’n cyfateb i 6 mis), ac nid yw’r amser hwn yn cyfrif tuag at y cyfnod o 5 mlynedd. Mae’n rhaid eu bod wedi byw ar wahân am fwy o amser i wneud i fyny am yr amser y bu iddynt fyw gyda’i gilydd.
cy.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceDesertionDe: Gadawodd yr atebydd y ceisydd heb ei gydsyniad o leiaf 2 flynedd yn ôl, ac maent wedi byw ar wahân ers hynny.

Mae gan y ceisydd a’r atebydd hawl i fod wedi byw gyda’i gilydd ers iddynt wahanu, ond dim ond am hyd at 6 mis (dros un cyfnod neu sawl cyfnod llai sy’n cyfateb i 6 mis), ac nid yw’r amser hwn yn cyfrif tuag at y cyfnod o 2 flynedd. Mae’n rhaid eu bod wedi byw ar wahân am fwy o amser i wneud i fyny am yr amser y bu iddynt fyw gyda’i gilydd.
Mae’n rhaid bod yr atebydd wedi dewis gadael y ceisydd. Er enghraifft, ni ellir defnyddio’r rheswm hwn os yw wedi ei (h)anfon i garchar.
